sources.data_found: Superior technical specs: 100 traditional CPU compute nodes, each with 16 Intel Sandy Bridge processors at 2.60 GHz and 64 GB RAM; 5 GPU-based compute nodes, each with four NVIDIA Tesla M2090 GPUs

Superior has 32 TFLOPS of CPU and 13 TFLOPS of GPU computing capacity. Intended for testing, educational, and gateway computing, the Portage cluster has 3 TFLOPS of CPU and 2 TFLOPS of GPU computing capacity.
College of Computing enrollment for Fall 2024: 837 undergraduate students
The college's fall enrollment is 869 undergraduate and graduate students
Computer Science MS, PhD Programs at Michigan Tech; GRE required for International Students only
Data Science in the College of Computing, where enrollment is up 14% from last year

student_data.notes: 837 total College of Computing undergraduates in Fall 2024. Given 869 total enrollment with 837 undergraduates, approximately 32 graduate students (869-837=32). Unable to find specific MS vs PhD breakdown.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Superior cluster has 5 GPU nodes × 4 Tesla M2090 GPUs each = 20 Tesla M2090 GPUs total

gpu_resources.notes: Michigan Tech's Superior cluster has 5 GPU-based compute nodes, each with 4 NVIDIA Tesla M2090 GPUs (5×4=20 total). These are older generation GPUs from ~2011. No evidence of newer GPU models (H100, A100, V100, etc.) in available public documentation.

analysis_notes: Michigan Tech appears to have limited GPU resources compared to peer institutions, with only 20 Tesla M2090 GPUs (older generation). The College of Computing has 837 undergraduate students and approximately 32 graduate students. Unable to find specific Computer Science department enrollment vs overall College of Computing enrollment.
